awd_titl_txt: The Internet of Things Coordination Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to establish a coordination network including representatives of industry, manufacturers, academia, and users of integrated smart devices. The "Internet of Things (IoT)" is the term used to describe the use and integration of smart devices capable of monitoring, controlling, collecting, sending, and receiving data to intelligent systems. The emergence of IoT will transform homes, institutions of education, manufacturing facilities, and other work places. As a new and rapidly emerging area of technology, IoT will generate a substantial need for technicians, technology integrators, and programmers. Community colleges across the nation are struggling with understanding and building programs to meet this future workforce need. As for other disruptive technologies, the emergence of IoT challenges educators to acquire the background knowledge needed to design high-quality IoT classes and programs. This collaboration network is designed to support the academic community at community colleges by studying the emergence of IoT technologies. The network plans to complete research projects on IoT products, technologies, standards, and applications.   The results of these studies will help to inform decisions about how to optimally develop IoT programs at community colleges.

The IoT Coordination Network aspires to bring together the principals and organizations that are leading the emergence of this technology. Members of this network include companies that manufacture and integrate IoT devices, and organizations that establish standards that govern IoT technologies. The network also intends to include experts on protecting the users and environments that are projected to be affected by these IoT devices. The project intends to convene this network of experts quarterly to examine emerging technologies, explore new products and devices, and provide guidance to educators preparing the next generation of IoT technicians.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major objectives of the IoT Coordination Network include:  

  • To formalize a public/private sector coordination network focusing on studying and supporting the emergence of Internet of Things (IoT) technician workforce.
  • Study and develop the core competencies, career pathways and instructional materials required to prepare the IIoT technician workforce.
  • Study and support the establishment of faculty development activities, industry credentials and assessment of core competencies associated with the training of IIoT technicians. 

The Coordination Network was able to accomplish the following outcomes.

  • Established a national advisory committee representing a diverse representation of new products in manufacturing, automation, healthcare, logistics, critical infrastructure and home automation. 
  • Collected, analyzed and published industry data required to identify core competencies of the future technical workforce associated with IIoT. 
  • Collected, analyzed and distributed data describing current community colleges, technical colleges, and 4-year colleges that offer degrees and certificates associated wit IIoT technologies.
  • Researched, collected and analyzed and developed a gap analysis of instructional materials that are needed to support workforce competencies for IIoT technicians.
  • Developed and delivered faculty development materials, workshops and classes for educators preparing technicians to support the technicians responsible for installing and maintaining IIoT.


The Coordination Network deliverables included the following items:

  • IIoT Technician Skills Map
  • IIoT Technician Multidisciplinary Learning Objectives
  • Survey of IIoT Technician Degrees And Certificates Currently Offered
  • Library of Lesson Plan Resources For IIoT Technician Programs
  • IIoT Technician Industry Domain Map & Network Tree

The Coordination Network had the following impact and results:

Published several reports and data regarding the development of technical education programs teaching IIoT trends, standards, technologies and products. These documents included the identification of knowledge, skills and abilities that should be included in future programs.  The documents also include a multitude of resources that are currently available to educators. The website portal tracked 224 unique faculty members who have requested access and downloaded resources.

 

The major purpose of this resource center was to identify and deliver academic and workforce data for institutions pursuing IIoT technician programs. However, the overwhelming response and requests from the academic community prompted us to offer professional development opportunities. The list below are the workshops and courses that were offered during the grant period.

IoT Fundamentals is the first course in the IoT Educators Academy.  It is intended to introduce instructors to the concepts of IoT, the Internet of Things, through a series of hands-on projects built around Arduino microcontrollers, an array of electronic components, sensors, and actuators
